content:
ry 8, 2012
												Quake is like Doom except the physics feel much nicer and you can jump, aim up and down and there's an increased emphasis on movement in general. The trade off is that there's smaller groups of enemies (rarely more than two at a time) and they're all a bit more bullet-spongey. The weapons can also be a tad unimaginative (no BFG here, just a gun that shoots lightning and chews through it's max amount of ammo in seconds).A lot of people dislike this game's visuals for relying a lot on the color brown. Personally, I don't mind this, as I feel that the more complex lighting and architecture of the maps (compared to Doom) compensates for this. That and the crappy low-poly monster models (that are still surprisingly well animated) combine with the rusted look of the game to create a wonderful aesthetic of low-tech creepiness. (I'd compare it to Silent Hill, but no part of Quake is ever set in a foggy town in the countryside - though there is at least one user-made map set in Innsmouth.)This game also has excellent sound design by NIN's Trent Reznor. Don't bother with that EpiQuake junk, the game's audio is perfect enough as it is ... and on that note, I have to explain exactly why I'm giving this a thumbs down, even though I've just been gushing about the game.It's because the Steam version doesn't include Trent Reznor's ambient soundtrack that Quake played off it's CD as in-game music. Unlike Hexen, there aren't any MIDI tracks or anything for the game to fall back on if the CD is missing - just nothing. The in-game sounds of wind and flickering torches are slightly more audible, and that's as good a compromise as you get.Now, I can understand the absence if it was a rights issue with Reznor, but that supposedly wasn't the case. Apparently, it was because when id put the Steam version of the game together (which runs in DOSBox) they couldn't figure out how to simply rip the tracks off the CD in OGG format and configure DOSBox to load those files in lieu of redbook audio. Maybe John Carmack was too busy working on his new engine for whatever that game no one cared about was called.Regardless, get Quake if you can find the original CD release on the cheap - which you probably will, as it's not a particularly rare game, nor one as valued by collectors as Doom (though be careful not to buy a  shareware version by accident). Alternatively, wait and see if this ever shows up on GOG.com - as those guys will probably put more effort into a basic digital release of this game than it's own developers.------------------TL;DR, Quake is a very good game, but don't buy it here or you will get a version without music.

content:
2015
												Quake is a classic FPS that, alongside Doom, helped Id Software codify the genre. How, I don't know, because Quake is an unbelievably boring game.The game's plot is, ostensibly, about fighting the Lovecraftian Old God Shub-Niggurath as she does... things. Which are bad. Quasi-demonic invasion from beyond the veil of space. As a Lovecraft fan this would seem rather encouraging... if in practice the game had any real plot at all. In practice the game is almost gleefully self-aware in how much its plot is a thin excuse to commit mass murder.Quake's "story" is broken up into four Episodes, of which I have admittedly only played the first two. The difference between the two seems to mostly be the upgrade of a single enemy type, and a slightly different wall texture. Any actual plot developments are mostly limited to easily-missed text blurbs at the end of each Episode, which mostly just seem to foreshadow the final boss.Gameplay-wise, Quake is a tedious, linear run-and-gun set in an endless parade of largely identical brown hallways against the same five brown enemies (with a few exceptions, like the odd miniboss and the very rare "Base" levels featuring soldiers and dogs, all similarly brown), in levels that offer no trace of setting, motivation, or purpose besides a playground to kill things on. The entire game could be proceedurally generated and you'd never notice.The combat itself is rather annoying. You're equipped with three main ammo types throughout the game - shotgun shells, nails, and rockets - and have two weapons for each, the second being a straight upgrade of the first (except for the grenade launcher and rocket launcher, which have different firing methods with different situational uses). In theory this weapon selection is servicable, but in practice it's rather lacking. Shotguns are the mainstay weapons of the game, probably to minimize the need to actually aim. Nailguns are vastly more effective weapons, basically being automatic weapons that have a degree of aim-assist to them, however their ammo is considerably more sparse and is burnt through much more quickly.None of this is really a dealbreaker, the truly annoying part is that this game is old enough to have multiple floors overlapping one another, but functionally lack the ability to look up or down. Star Wars: Dark Forces had a similar conundrum mostly solved by the fact that most weapons would aim up or down for you in a limited cone, and your enemies had similar limitations. However, in Quake the most common enemy by far is the Ogre, a stocky brute with a middling level of health and equipped with a chainsaw and a grenade launcher. Bullets shoot straight, but grenades arc with gravity and bounce around corners. Cue every single level filled to the gills with Ogres on high ledges where as often as not you can't hit them, but they will gleefully pelt an endless stream of grenades down on your head.Don't make the mistake of me blaming my dislike of this game on it's difficulty. I died plenty, but I'm describing the game's combat as "annoying," not "difficult." Quake's uncomplicated setup makes it difficult for anything to become legitimately unbalanced, but managable does not mean fun. And when you take combat that isn't particularly fun, a plot that barely exists, and repetitive, bland aesthetics, you get a game that has essentially no merits to recommend.

ry 25
												THIS.THIS ♥♥♥♥ING GAME.If H.P Lovecraft, the heavy metal of the nineties, and the intense atmosphere of Doom was smashed, reconstructed, smashed again and reconstructed again into a glorious product, it would be Quake.Unlike Doom, where it pitches at you various demons from hell, Quake throws in horrific eldritch beings in their place. We still have the loveable zombies from the last game, but instead of Cacodemons we have Scrags. Instead of Revenants, we have Vores. Instead of Cyberdemons, we have Shamblers.The weapons have changed as well. Instead of fists, you get a bloody axe that is more useless than trying to cut down a tree with a herring. The Pistol has been ditched for a Shotgun, which is unfortunatly not as fun to use as Doom's shotgun. The Super Shotgun returns as well, and it somewhat becomes a mainstay later on ingame. Instead of a chaingun, we get the Nailgun and Super Nailgun, which are FUN AS HELL TO USE. One new addition is the Grenade Launcher (Which bizarrely shares the Rocket Launchers ammo pool), which can take out groups of bad guys in no time. Theres not much to talk about the Rocket Launcher, aside from its amazing "Rocket Jump" capability. Finally, we have the Thunderbolt. Think of this tool as the games version to a Plasma Gun/BFG 9000 combo. It does not have much ammo, so use it in the most lethal of situations. The game has such a forboding atmosphere, at times I felt as though something would actually sneak up on me and rip me to shreds. Combine it with the soundtrack made by Nine Inch Nails, and this game will make you feel more nihilistic than the ending of the first F.E.A.R. Tldr;BUY THIS GAME, OR I WILL ♥♥♥♥ING ♥♥♥♥ YOUR DOG IN THE DEAD OF NIGHT. I AM NOT KIDDING. BUY THE GAME RIGHT NOplease help my family is being held hostage by john romero he has me at gunpoint

er 17, 2013
												Ah, the Classic Quake. The first true 3D FPS game. 13 years on, how well has it aged?Surprisingly well actually. I suppose the first thing to note is that the game played a lot like DooM, I personally like to consider it one of the 3 DooM 3's also consisting of DooM64 and the actual DooM 3. But I Digress.Quake, as the first FPS to use actual Ploygons manages to hold up quite well, you have the basic DooM style controls, using the arrow keys to turn, Ctrl to shoot and WASD to move (That is unless you're using the Ultimate Quake Patch, but I'll get to that later). and it does feel like a well-rounded experience that manages to hold up today. Of course it has graphically aged poorly with Jerky animation (this can be fixed with the UQP) but to fully enjoy the game you have to put your mindset back in 1996 where the best looking 3D was Virtua Fighter, This game puts you in a realisting looking (for the time) environments and gives frigtening enemies that have never been seen before.Story Wise the game doesn't offer much, but the game doesn't really need to, you're just a guy (Who I like to call Quakeguy) who must stop evil creatures from an Alternate Dimension. It is sweet and simple.All weapons handle well, from the Shotgun, Nailgun, Their 'Super' Counterparts, Rocket Launcher, Grenade Launcher, all are simplistic in their design and manage to hit their target with a bit of help from auto aim (Again, UQP). The game features a fun Fast paced game that is perfect for speedrunners and delivers on the retro feeling and boasts great level design.The Enemies themselves are actually made creepier with an effect that would not exist if the game had more polygons, The Gothic scenery makes the mood and feel of the game and gives the game It's own unique identity.Unfortunatly the game has some problems cause by some sort of steam optimisation. The Music is Non-Existant, even though there exists OST tracks on YouTube, none are featured in this game. This is Where the Ultimate Quake Patch comes into effect. The UQP fixes a lot of the Steam problems as well as some more of the poorly aged parts: Enemies have now got fluent animation, Mouse Control is Enabled, Improved Lighting and Particle effects as well as the OST added. Personally though I thought the 1996 graphics and improved lighting and effects were too distracting and I had no idea how to get the game to look like the Original game with just the Soundtrack so I removed it. The game still has a great Charm to it and is memorable for it's environments and enemies. The game is still fun without the UQP but may turn people off with the lack of soundtrack.I suppose the bottom line is that Quake is a Good, if not Great game the has fun retro gameplay but naturally has not aged well in many areas. This leads to 3 possiblities for interest in the consumers purchase:1) Buy the game on GOG where it (apparently) plays Just like the Steam release but with working OST2) Buy on Steam with UQP, if you aren't bothered by the clashing graphics and enjoy updated versions of old games then this should be fine for you3) Just buy the Steam release as it is and Play some 'Through the Fire and Flames' to the game and enjoy it for what it is.Quake is a Landmark in the FPS genre that doesn't hold up as well as it's older brothers DooM and Wolfenstein but leaves it's mark in it's creative level design and fun fast gameplay.FINAL VERDICT: RECCOMEND

y 8, 2014
												Quake is one of the first FPS games that is fully rendered in 3D.  Now it is more of an interactive museum piece than an entertaining game, but still has a little charm for those who really fell in love with the FPS genre when it grew big.  The guns are creative and semi-traditional, as well as the enemies.  This is also one of the first games to offer enemies that will fight each other when they get caught in crossfire.  This game also was one of the first games to be openly modded, but most mods have not been carried over from the past.  Multiplayer mods have to be downloaded separately from the base game.  I still enjoy this game once in awhile, but this is one of those gems that is simply more hard rock than actual diamond.

ber 9, 2014
												When it comes to first person shooter games, I've almost always preferred the old to the new. Games like Doom, Duke Nukem 3D, Team Fortress Classic, and most importantly, this game. Quake is one of my favorite games of all time, and a top contender for my favorite first person shooter. If you are a gamer that enjoys reloading constantly, passively regenerating health, being guided linearly from point A to point B in the story, and generally playing behind a safety net, then good for you. But Quake is a fast paced, old school, top of the class shooter that refuses to hold your hand. The fast paced gameplay, the need for exploration to find every secret to help you through, the challenging, hard hitting enemies and weapons, and the fact that you can die extremely quickly if you screw up. That is what a good shooter is to me, and I can't think of a better example of where that shines than Quake. If you haven't played this game before, I can't recommend it enough, and if you're a long time fan of the Quake series like me, then you understand why I feel the way I do about this game. 10/10.

												Quake Pioneered the following innovation in First Person Shooters:-Recharging personal shields (every FPS today copies it)-Dual wielding-Dedicated grenade button-Dedicated melee button (melee is actually useful in Quake)-Complex characters (Ranger, Shub-Niggurath)-Involving and deep storyline-Saved PC gaming-Made LAN parties cool-Saving and sharing replays-First ever FPS to include a map editor-Perfectly streamlined online play-Vehicles-It is so good that games nowadays are referred to as "Quake clones," and some, like Unreal, try to be a "Quake killer"-Orchestral music (before it everything was just bleepbloop synthesized music)-AI that becomes more intelligent on higher difficulties instead of just having more health.

												This game still stands as a unique, abstract shooter with a thickly-dark atmosphere.   No storyline; just a series of demonic mazes and fast action.  I lost much of my youth caught up in the multiplayer aspect of this game.  Gameplay-wise, it's a  basic but smooth formula.  It offers a challenge that is purely skill based; not just on your aim; but your timing, prediction and almost gymnastic movement around the levels.I still think it's a technical marvel.  This was one of the first full-3D games; and the levels are deliberately vertical and abstract in their design.  Everything has long since been open sourced; as a coder it's intriguing to inspect the design from a kind of archeological perspective.When starting, you're given the option to choose which executable to run;  QuakeWorld (which was its brilliant online version - though surely not noob friendly), didn't work for me.   Perhaps with some technical tinkering you can get this to work.  (It was never straightforward back in the day anyway)I've tested the GLQuake option, is the hardware rendering option, this works without any issues.  I'm sure there are mods out there that improve the experience, though.Gamers today will probably never feel the same sense of awe and wonder and compelling multiplayer gameplay as we did when it released.  I'm kinda glad that games have moved on though, this game has a slightly discomforting pull, like it's almost half-living, a demon demanding my return.   As a skeptical atheist, it's beyond disturbing.My time with this game is done;  it was a strange friend that was always present, but I hardly miss.  It still quietly haunts my subconscious to this day.   Damn.

ry 22, 2013
												Truly one of my favorite video games of all time. For the time, the graphics were stunning and unfathomable. Even in an age of much better graphics, I still thoroughly enjoy looking about the levels and marveling at the superb design. The soundtrack is very fitting with the atmosphere that is placed around and creates a sense of immersion. The story is not clearly explained and is not emotional or anything but compelling enough to keep you blasting through enemies and exploring the environment. The gameplay is what to be expected, a fantasically crafted simple yet enjoyable first person shooter that screams everything is classic about this game. I would recommend this game to anyone in the world, even if they do not play video games often. This is a must play for anyone and everyone, this fine piece of gaming history should be known to all.  Quake is not just a game, but a whole culture that has culminated a certain part of video game history that still stands today in 2016. As one of my favorite games, even today, I can recommend this game to anyone. The graphics are not the absolute best, but were still revolutionary at the time. The sound is nostalgic to all of those that stayed up late nights playing with their friends blasting eachother with the crazy fun arsenal of weapnry. The environments took you to places that were quite unique for the time and somehow made sense to be designed the way that they were and not only that, but enjoyable to the average gamer. Furthermore, I think if the graphics get to you now, there are still modders that have improved on that to either get new players to experience it or bring some older players a new experience.

												An absolutely fantastic game with smooth gameplay despite it`s age. The overall design and atmosphere within the game is astounding and can be genuinely frightening if played on higher difficulty settings such as nightmare, not through arbitrary and scripted sequences, but through the enemy design and gameplay. HOWEVER, I must stress that despite this, a newer sourceport such as quakespasm or darkspaces is recommended due to the original engine not having aged too well.I personally recommend Darkplaces due to it`s compatibility and options such as FOV sliders and customisable lighting and effects, allowing you to give the game some visual upgrades.The weapons all serve great purpose and some damage enemies better than others, combined with the unique behaviour of each, the player is left with a game of great challenge and intrigue. The game features a well composed soundtrack by Nine inch nails and their logo can be seen on ammunition containers throughout.While the game is definitely not perfect, it is a game that any oldschooler would be incredibly comfortable with, however newschool players may find it less.Overall a solid gold piece of the past, not for everyone but for me, it was a good time.

er 23, 2016
												Ah, Quake...how much we, the gamers of the 21st century owe thee So much of the technology and so many of the conventions we now take for granted were developed for this game. So many great games were built within the Quake engine or its immediate derivatives. It is truly a landmark of gaming history. Some of the greatest geniusus of game development history invested their talents into this game and changed the industry forever.But that's not why you should buy Quake. You should buy this game because it is still one of the best shooters ever made. It's stilll scary and exciting in equal measure. Its design is still darkly original, it's arsenal still finely balanced, and its gameplay still wickely slick.Once you are done with the ~9 hour campaign, why not check out the multiplayer that remains active more than twenty years after the game's release (if that's not proof enough of Quake's superiority, then nothing is). Or perhaps you could head over to Quaddicted.com and try any one of the 1200 user-made single player maps and map packs.For two decades Quake has been an unexhaustable source of pleasure for gamers and I full expect to still be basking in its glory twenty years hence.

												(I played this through Darkplaces so my hours will not show up on here.) Quake is one of the best FPS games I have ever played. The setting and weapons were just so unique. The soundtrack is absolutly superb and was composed by Trent Reznor of Nine Inch Nails. Quake's story and gameplay is very similar to DOOM's except this was created in a true 3D engine. IMPORTANT: As of right now the soundtrack does not work with the Steam version so if your not willing to fiddle with a Source Port and some audio downloads your going to be out of luck as far as music is concerned. The game is very Lovecraftian themed (Cthulhu, etc). You'll encounter demonic knights with swords, strange creatures of all shapes and sizes, zombified soldiers, and THE SHAMBLER. Quake has an episode based level design so you will go through one episode tackling a whole bunch of levels and then be put back into a hub area in order to select the next episode. There are four episodes in total. This game oozes immersion and atmosphere. You may play hours of it without notice sometimes. I would recommend this game to anyone into 90's FPS such as DOOM or Duke. This game is not just a game. It is an experience.

ber 6, 2015
												Quake is essentially DOOM with some way-ahead-of-its-time 3-D graphics. While the game is great, I liked DOOM and Duke Nukem 3D(Not an "id Software" title) much more.Quake doesn't really have much going for it in setting and monsters. I like the whole goth/demon setting but it gets boring and uninteresting after awhile, even if the levels are designed well. DOOM has the advantage over Quake because the levels are more elaborate and fun to killyour way through with more interesting demons, and Duke 3D has the advantage over Quake because of its humour, creativity and extreme interactiveness that manages to make the player much more immersed even without the early 3D technology Quake has. Here the monsters were okay at best. Nothing to write home about. Although the final boss, while a letdown did look extremely cool.That isn't to say that this is bad, Quake still has your fun puzzle-based gameplay that Doom and Duke have to offer. If you play the game on the "Hard" difficulty you'll have a fun little challenge playing through the campaign. I'm sure if you would have played this game when it came out you would have crapped in your pants at the graphics. However, given the fact that Duke Nukem 3D and Shadow Warrior both include the game and their expansions redone for a mere 9.99, Quake only gives you the base game for 9.99 and makes you pay 4.99 for each respective expansion. I'd recommend saving this one for the old Steam Sale.Other things of note: It kind of sucks that the face of your character that gets progressively more and more bloodied from damage doesn't move or blink like that of Doomguy's from Doom and also the grunting noise your character makes when you jump will never leave your brain.

6, 2016
												Quake is everything that the fans of the series claimed it would be. Quake follows the ranger (the protagonist) as he goes about collecting the 4 legendary runes in order to stop the Shub-Niggurath. The theme of interdimensional beings invading Earth seemed to be a popular theme among the time. The game is split into 4 episodes and the final boss fight. You can access any episode from the hub which has a great layout that I really enjoyed. Each episode is a decent length with around 7 or 8 levels, and the levels themselves usually have a few puzzles in order to keep you from just speed running it like in the DOOM franchise. The movement is fast paced allowing for you to easily out maneuver your opponent, while also keeping things from getting stale. The weapons in Quake are all unique in their own way some more useful than others. The enemies of Quake seem to share an eldritch horror style and are each unique with some requiring certain weapons to defeat them. The graphics in Quake invoke a nostalgic feel but are also heavily outdated. I did not play the multiplayer as I am sure that there are few servers if any at all still running. Quake does everything right that I wanted from a game like Doom and I had a fun time going through the story and playing through this gem of a game.

I did bump up the resolution from its default to something abit more modern, and it takes abit of getting used to(again) the fact that the mouse-looking is just side-to-side, but it doesn't matter at all, though there are keyboard keys for looking up-down. ***This game still holds up today, 20 years after its release.  You will quickly realize how much hand-holding is built into today's games!  Quake is THE game that made me a PC gamer.***It has been brought to my attention that there are various mods available that address certain 'quirks' of Quake that may make the game more enjoyable/accessible to modern gamers.

												The obvious stuff-A great FPS, I'll say. Better than most choices these days, but IMO it doesn't beat its sequel or Unreal. Why is that, for me anyway? Because its sequel was my first game ever, I learned to love the sci-fi look on it and get used to it rather than the Lovecraftian style that I came to experience some time after. Same goes for the music, a lot of people are going to hate me for this but I dislike most of the music for this game, with the exception of its main theme and the 'base' theme of every first level of each area. I really like those two, the theme's badass and the base music is relaxing, in a way. I really hate one of the tracks, the one with the piano and then you hear a voice that's like hearing someone dragging their finger nail down a chalkboard. Seriously, that's what I hear everytime I hear the song and its headache-giving, to me anyway, don't let that affect what you might experience. Sorry if I did. :/This game IS less repetitive than Doom, I'll give it that, its great for what it is, MUCH better than CoD, BF, and so on. I know I kinda already said that before but I really need to get that out there. This game's great, but only if you have bought and played others that might be better.The Stuff you'd probably need to know before you buy the darn game-You start out at a Hub that lets you select your difficulty, you proceed to such difficulty and you enter another hub that allows you to select the area of which will allow you to gain a rune. Such runes allow you to gain enough power to gain access to find the game's boss. You collect the runes by reaching the end of the area, that being the area's last level. The first area is the only one that has a scripted boss, the others are all walking enemies, though they can be considered bosses too, the game can get much harder depending on the area's number. You can finish the game pretty quickly, and its also easily speedrunnable if you know how to. Its overall very fun and as I said, only get it if you already played stuff that could be better. Get it on a sale if you want, I am known for being cheap like an old man so I dunno, I always tell people to buy stuff on a sale because its totally worth it. :p

												It has been many years since I played the first Quake...literally up until now I probably haven't played it since the first year or two the game was out.THE drawback from this game on Steam is no music at all which was a dissapointment.However I hold a candle to this particular game because none of them equalled the first.They were good but couldn't capture the magic of the first because they didn't stick to the formula.Lots of great level design and light sourcing as the first taste of 3D polygonal shooters.Riddled with traps and an interesting variety of monsters and coming back to this game I'd say the same monsters would still be good if they kept 'breeding the variety'.Who doesn't like a chainsaw weilding maniac lobbing grenades at you...hearing that tell-tale clang..clang..clang..as they ricochet off walls or bounce on the floor.Or even better-the nailgun and super nailgun as that's a sub for a machine gun...that just adds butchery to this dark 3D shooter.

, 2013
												Oh Quake, how I love thee.  Quake II was my introduction into First-Person Shooter, and after I had absorbed as much of it as I could I went to its predecessor and played that.  And boy are they different games.The funny thing about Quake is how different the games have been.  First there is Quake with a gothic feel that isn’t far from the Doom mold. Then you have Quake 2, which wasn’t intended on being a Quake game until they were unable to gain the rights they were looking for, and decided to just use the name Quake II.  It has a very technological theme with aliens.  After which there was Quake III Arena, which took all the great things created and learned from Quake and Quake II’s multiplayer, making almost a third setting/storyline, with characters from previous ID titles.  And finally there is Quake 4, which is a direct sequel to Quake II, back the the technological aliens.  And there is rumor of the next Quake game going back to the gothic style.While the story isn’t entirely there, Quake is ultimately an excellent game.  And maybe it’s simply because I just played all the great games in the right order.  Where each game fed into the next, and really displayed how they were truly remarkable.

												Being, as it is, the last game before John Romero's ill-fated departure from the legendary id Software, this is as much a piece of gaming history as it is a game.don't be fooled by that description, this is one hell of a game, while its graphics and gameplay are dated now, there is still that visceral thrill similar to DOOM that is timeless. sure, newer and arguably better games have been and gone since the mid-1990s, there is still something compelling about Quake, something that hasn't really been captured since Timesplitters: Future Perfect. while the steam version isn't perfect (it's lacking the music from the cd version, something that can be rectified with mods), it is still a visceral thrill to play, and in a first for id software, you start with the shotgun, meaning the awesome starts right at the beginning.the fast-paced action present in this game that, may i remind you, is nearly 20 years old will keep you coming back for decades to come. it is as timeless as super mario bros.

, 2013
												Oh Quake, how I love thee.  Quake II was my introduction into First-Person Shooter, and after I had absorbed as much of it as I could I went to its predecessor and played that.  And boy are they different games.The funny thing about Quake is how different the games have been.  First there is Quake with a gothic feel that isn’t far from the Doom mold. Then you have Quake 2, which wasn’t intended on being a Quake game until they were unable to gain the rights they were looking for, and decided to just use the name Quake II.  It has a very technological theme with aliens.  After which there was Quake III Arena, which took all the great things created and learned from Quake and Quake II’s multiplayer, making almost a third setting/storyline, with characters from previous ID titles.  And finally there is Quake 4, which is a direct sequel to Quake II, back the the technological aliens.  And there is rumor of the next Quake game going back to the gothic style.While the story isn’t entirely there, Quake is ultimately an excellent game.  And maybe it’s simply because I just played all the great games in the right order.  Where each game fed into the next, and really displayed how they were truly remarkable.

												Quake is undeniable. If you're on this store page, you shouldn't need me to tell you how great Quake is, but I am here to assure you that, with a few little patches, you can still play the Quake of your memories.The Steam version, like most digital copies, doesn't include the soundtrack, and GabeN obviously doesn't much care for physical media, so there's not much chance of him sending you a CD. Don't dismay, though. There are all kinds of guides to get the soundtrack up and running, and what a difference it makes! The memories of countless hours spent fragging came flooding back. A few graphical tweaks, and the game actually looks as good as I thought it did the first time I saw it played.If you ever enjoyed Quake, or if you're some kind of child or mutant who's never played before, you owe it to yourself to drop the paltry sum, and experience this masterpiece of foundational game design (foundational to its genre, at any rate) again, or for the first time.

er 25, 2014
												What's there to say about Quake? One of the most world-renowned and memorable FPS' of all time. But why is that the case? Let's take a detailed look and see:1. Gameplay - Let's trim the fat and get right to the guts right off the bat; Quake's gameplay is that of your typical 90's old-school FPS: Fast, bloody, complex and hard as hell, and you will love it (if you're into FPS games, that is). You get a wide array of weapons from a harmless Axe to the dreaded Thunderbolt, which turns any enemy into mincemeat in seconds, including the dreaded Shambler. Also like any old-school FPS, it is rife with secret areas that are a chore to find, but well worth the rewards within! Most times, at least. Tons of pick ups like the Pentagram of Protection (Invulnerability), Ring of Shadows (Invisibility), and the all-too-memorable Quad Damage, allowing you to unleash doomsday to every enemy in sight -- and yourself, too, if you aren't careful! -- dealing a massive 400% damage with any weapon you choose! There is a wide variety of enemies you will also encounter, from the annoying Grunt to the creepy Vore. Hint: When you see a Fiend (the bipedal, ape-like thing with lacerator arms) run like hell. One leap attack, and you're near dead. No joke.2. Graphics - Usually graphics aren't one thing to take too seriously in reviews. In my philosophy, so long as you can see where you are going, and nothing looks TOO pixelated, they're perfectly tolerable. Buuuuuuuuut, that being said, download the Ultimate Quake Patch to be able to play this game in buttery-smooth 1920x1080 (if you have a full HD monitor that is). Never before has a game from the 90's looked so crisp and clear. And to think at one point I thought the 320x240 resolution of Quake on the N64 was the best thing ever. *shudders*3. Difficulty - Hoo, boy...if you are brave enough to play this game on Nightmare (which you should to get the full experience, as cliche as that may sound, I know), this game will keep you on the edge of your seat nearly at all times, especially once you start encountering the bigger, badder enemies in later levels. Also, beware the Spawns (the bouncy slime-things). Just...just trust me on this.4. Replay value - I could start this beauty up and play it any day of the week and have fun with it. It's fast-paced, bloody FPS action at its finest, and one of the true granddaddies of the FPS genre, along with Doom, Wolfenstein 3D and Duke Nukem 3D.Bottom Line: You want this game. It's usually like, $3 or something. Absolute steal and a half. As are the expansions! But I'll review those by themselves.

, 2012
												Simply put, my favorite FPS of all time.  Impeccable level design, great enemies with really good AI for the time, and an environment and mob placement that actually lends itself to be legitimately scary.  It has surprises that you're usually ready for, but you're not the golden god you are in most FPS games where after the initial startle, you realize you can not be stopped and then wait until the next cheap shock.  Brilliant weapons, an awesome soundtrack and very cool odes to Lovecraftian lore make this a title that no gamer should ever have to claim they have not played.  If you love the Halos and Call of Duties now and have not taken a step back in time to play this gem, then make sure to put it on  your list.  You won't regret it.

2, 2014
												Roughly 32 hours in, I finally managed to beat all of Episode 1 (including Ziggurat Vertigo) on Nightmare difficulty.  To think I played the first level or two of this game over and over as a kid, having no idea how hard this game acutally is, is pretty crazy to think about.This game plays PERFECTLY on Windows 10 with no mods/additions of any kind, never froze or crashed on me, and I was honestly suprised about that considering the age of the game.  I play using a GeForce GT 650M (Laptop), and once you find the right aspect ratio, the game is actually very kind on the eye (assuming no graphics mods).The movement is so fluid, as is with all Quake titles, but this is the game that started it all, and if you only played it a little bit as a kid, then you definitely need to play it now (if you love a good FPS).Basically I spent $9.99 (bought it off sale) and 32 hours later I like it so much I was compelled to type a review for it.  I have been playing it completely bare-bones, even with OG graphics and I have loved every moment of it.  Highly recommended, and from my experience, you shouldn't need to worry about weather it will play on your rig or not.

												Such an Iccon of its time and every bit as groundbreaking as Doom was. This is where MP deathmatch began with the likes of Doom and Quake. The Singleplayer level design is built in such a way that it is always fun to explore. The levels are riddled with secret passages, areas and even secret levels. Modern games could learn a lot from games such as these when it comes to level design. The sounds are just as creepy as I remember them. The success of Doom 2016 shows that these types of games are still very playable with modern graphics. I very much hope that a new singlepayer Quake campaign will happen in very much the same way as it did with Doom. For fast paced twitch shooting and fun levels... you cant get much better than this!

												if you suck at tf2 or want to be better at it, here is your steps (a useful advice for the f2p players of tf2)1) get quake on steam and the two mission packs2)intall quake3)get a fan made patches for quake and the mission packs, the next best thing to rocket jumpinghttp://forums.steampowered.com/forums/showthread.php?t=17569234)play singleplayer of quake and get familiar with the mechanics which are very similar to tf2re 4)while playing, play with style that fits you, quake allows you to play anyway you want while progressing through the game5)play multiplayer, and gid gud, and don't forget to have fun while getting good at the game6)after learning most of the important mechanics, apply these skills you aquired from  quake to tf27)???8)profit!and off the record step, don't forget to revisit and play quake again to pay tribute to the timeless classic that shaped games like tf2 and have fun with it again.A side note, this graphics thing, sure it doesn't look as good as the modern day graphics, but it was made in 1997 and the visuals where ground breaking at that time. The visuals still looks authentic to me and original, you can get the fancy texture mod for quake but it wouldn't feel as authentic as classic visuals of quake. For me, the graphics are made for the first impression (to see the beauty of how many colourful pixels there are on the screen), but its the asthetic, the gameplay, and the little stuff that don't include the graphics, which makes the game like quake memorable that you can just revisit and appresiate what its going for compared modern shooters. But I digress, the quake visuals are still appealing to this day. It is still great that you can run this on the modern rigs on any os flawlessly which blew my mind and that is awesome (and this game runs great, no fps drops, the fan patches makes the game alot more enjoyable and the steam version is crap). I love quake, and will revisit it again when I feel like in a quake mood."Shake it baby, SHAKE! But I ain't gonna quake" - serious sam

er 29, 2014
												Quake is undeniable. If you're on this store page, you shouldn't need me to tell you how great Quake is, but I am here to assure you that, with a few little patches, you can still play the Quake of your memories.The Steam version, like most digital copies, doesn't include the soundtrack, and GabeN obviously doesn't much care for physical media, so there's not much chance of him sending you a CD. Don't dismay, though. There are all kinds of guides to get the soundtrack up and running, and what a difference it makes! The memories of countless hours spent fragging came flooding back. A few graphical tweaks, and the game actually looks as good as I thought it did the first time I saw it played.If you ever enjoyed Quake, or if you're some kind of child or mutant who's never played before, you owe it to yourself to drop the paltry sum, and experience this masterpiece of foundational game design (foundational to its genre, at any rate) again, or for the first time.

ry 16, 2015
												I absolutely loved this game, this game is so good I'm not sure why a remake hasn't been made yet. It mixes gothic horror (think Edgar Allen Poe and H.P. Lovecraft), freakishly monstrous monsters (Zombies with chainsaws bro {need I say more}), and the awesomeness of first person gameplay. Add in a soundtrack done by Trent Reznor of Nine Inch Nails and you've got yourself one scary but awesome game. One of the easiest bosses to defeat too but I'll let you guess witch one. er 25, 2014
												What's there to say about Quake? One of the most world-renowned and memorable FPS' of all time. But why is that the case? Let's take a detailed look and see:1. Gameplay - Let's trim the fat and get right to the guts right off the bat; Quake's gameplay is that of your typical 90's old-school FPS: Fast, bloody, complex and hard as hell, and you will love it (if you're into FPS games, that is). You get a wide array of weapons from a harmless Axe to the dreaded Thunderbolt, which turns any enemy into mincemeat in seconds, including the dreaded Shambler. Also like any old-school FPS, it is rife with secret areas that are a chore to find, but well worth the rewards within! Most times, at least. Tons of pick ups like the Pentagram of Protection (Invulnerability), Ring of Shadows (Invisibility), and the all-too-memorable Quad Damage, allowing you to unleash doomsday to every enemy in sight -- and yourself, too, if you aren't careful! -- dealing a massive 400% damage with any weapon you choose! There is a wide variety of enemies you will also encounter, from the annoying Grunt to the creepy Vore. Hint: When you see a Fiend (the bipedal, ape-like thing with lacerator arms) run like hell. One leap attack, and you're near dead. No joke.2. Graphics - Usually graphics aren't one thing to take too seriously in reviews. In my philosophy, so long as you can see where you are going, and nothing looks TOO pixelated, they're perfectly tolerable. Buuuuuuuuut, that being said, download the Ultimate Quake Patch to be able to play this game in buttery-smooth 1920x1080 (if you have a full HD monitor that is). Never before has a game from the 90's looked so crisp and clear. And to think at one point I thought the 320x240 resolution of Quake on the N64 was the best thing ever. *shudders*3. Difficulty - Hoo, boy...if you are brave enough to play this game on Nightmare (which you should to get the full experience, as cliche as that may sound, I know), this game will keep you on the edge of your seat nearly at all times, especially once you start encountering the bigger, badder enemies in later levels. Also, beware the Spawns (the bouncy slime-things). Just...just trust me on this.4. Replay value - I could start this beauty up and play it any day of the week and have fun with it. It's fast-paced, bloody FPS action at its finest, and one of the true granddaddies of the FPS genre, along with Doom, Wolfenstein 3D and Duke Nukem 3D.Bottom Line: You want this game. It's usually like, $3 or something. Absolute steal and a half. As are the expansions! But I'll review those by themselves.

												Ah, Quake...how much we, the gamers of the 21st century owe thee So much of the technology and so many of the conventions we now take for granted were developed for this game. So many great games were built within the Quake engine or its immediate derivatives. It is truly a landmark of gaming history. Some of the greatest geniusus of game development history invested their talents into this game and changed the industry forever.But that's not why you should buy Quake. You should buy this game because it is still one of the best shooters ever made. It's stilll scary and exciting in equal measure. Its design is still darkly original, it's arsenal still finely balanced, and its gameplay still wickely slick.Once you are done with the ~9 hour campaign, why not check out the multiplayer that remains active more than twenty years after the game's release (if that's not proof enough of Quake's superiority, then nothing is). Or perhaps you could head over to Quaddicted.com and try any one of the 1200 user-made single player maps and map packs.For two decades Quake has been an unexhaustable source of pleasure for gamers and I full expect to still be basking in its glory twenty years hence.

er 24, 2014
 Overview One of the oldest FPS' out there. Even to this day, the pixelated display (Which can be sorted with a retextured version named 'Quake Epsilon'), retro music, run and gun themes and level design still retain at least some of their widespread popularity. Definitely not for hipster gamers, who play their stupid little 2d pixel 'art' games, this is for real gamers who need a little trip down memory lane.  System Quake runs as it should, anything that causes too much trouble rarely occurs. The controls aren't too hard to master, plus they aren't buggy (As I've found with some other olden games). The controls aren't dissimilar from most modern-day games, with the exception of specialised buttons like turn left 5 degrees or something. It's just point and shoot. No need to reload. Multiplayer The one thing that doesn't really work well in the original Quake is the co-op/multiplayer. It is usually pretty buggy and laggy, and controls have been known to break and/or unbind in a match. Plus, the multiplayer mechanics don't really gel with each other. Sometimes, the AI will just completely break down and enemies will just stare in the direction the editors placed them in and won't attack or move. This also means entities with any properties won't activate or do anything. The single player campaign is good enough on its own, however. Conclusion This game is very good, considering the times it was made in. Newer versions have been released (The aforementioned Quake Epsilon) that make it easier to see what's actually happening. For such an old game, Quake still remains impressive and a fun experience. It may be like Destiny story-wise (It has none), but it certainly makes for a fun pick-up-and-play game when you're bored. 8/10.Alright, we're done here.

r 2, 2014
												Being, as it is, the last game before John Romero's ill-fated departure from the legendary id Software, this is as much a piece of gaming history as it is a game.don't be fooled by that description, this is one hell of a game, while its graphics and gameplay are dated now, there is still that visceral thrill similar to DOOM that is timeless. sure, newer and arguably better games have been and gone since the mid-1990s, there is still something compelling about Quake, something that hasn't really been captured since Timesplitters: Future Perfect. while the steam version isn't perfect (it's lacking the music from the cd version, something that can be rectified with mods), it is still a visceral thrill to play, and in a first for id software, you start with the shotgun, meaning the awesome starts right at the beginning.the fast-paced action present in this game that, may i remind you, is nearly 20 years old will keep you coming back for decades to come. it is as timeless as super mario bros.

												Quake Pioneered the following innovation in First Person Shooters:-Recharging personal shields (every FPS today copies it)-Dual wielding-Dedicated grenade button-Dedicated melee button (melee is actually useful in Quake)-Complex characters (Ranger, Shub-Niggurath)-Involving and deep storyline-Saved PC gaming-Made LAN parties cool-Saving and sharing replays-First ever FPS to include a map editor-Perfectly streamlined online play-Vehicles-It is so good that games nowadays are referred to as "Quake clones," and some, like Unreal, try to be a "Quake killer"-Orchestral music (before it everything was just bleepbloop synthesized music)-AI that becomes more intelligent on higher difficulties instead of just having more health.

24, 2016
												For this Steam edition, be aware that you don't get any music at all in Quake. Apparently there is a work around, but when one purchases a game they should get the full content.  Otherwise, all seems to be well in the delivery of the game.Quake itself wasn't quite all the gaming public had hoped for back in the mid 90s.   The music, visual design and action seemed quite dull compared to the hell-ride that was Doom, whilst the "full 3D levels" didn't seem to impress as much with competition from console games such as Super Mario 64 and Tomb Raider - which both offered smooth character animations where Quake's creatures-from-the-abyss were very jerky...That said, this game still manages to be a mile stone in gaming history.  Its multiplayer culture was massive back in the day and for years to come, and somehow, there is a gritty and creepy menace to the games characters - the jerky animation is actually a strength in this regard.  While Doom was Id's finest hour, Quake is still a highlight for the Texas-based developer.  Go grab a horror/action soundtrack CD from an old film and set it running before loading up Quake, and you'll be pleasantly surprised how delightfully nasty this classic game can be...Oh, for those wondering how to look around with the mouse; open the console and type "+mlook" and press enter.

												Playing this on my Rift using the Quakespasm engine with VR modifications. It is hands down the best VR experience I've had so far. Quake is a timeless classic. The map design, sound design and aesthetics really spring to life when played in VR. I can hardly recommend this enough.Keep in mind that Quake on Steam doesn't support VR. You only need the pak files from the Steam game, then add them to the Quakegasm engine with the VR modifications. Then run Quakegasm and voila! You're teleported to the freakish world of Quake. er 27, 2016
												Quake is one of those games that, despite its flaws, has stood the test of time like few others. id made an incredible job of using their limitations to their advantage. The combat is much more close quarters than his cousin Doom due to polycount restrictions, resulting in a much more oppresive experience and tactical interplay between enemy and level design that keeps the game varied without any need for character progression. The monochrome palette flourishes in its lower Middle Age / Lovecraftian setting, evoking a sense of gloom and pestilence that never allows you to be comfortable in any place. Even the dated visuals add to a sense of charm.PROS: A precious blend of atmosphere and fast-paced combat and pure unadulterated fun, stuffed with secrets and power-ups in the best 1990s game tradition.CONS: The mouse controls are the part that has stood worst the test of time, and would really benefit from a revamp (can be modded though). If you can't use 3D acceleration, the highest resolutions run the game at truly unplayable framerates.8/10Buy it whether you played in its day or not, for a timeless piece of History.If one game needs a Doom-like reboot by id Software, is this one.

er 19, 2016
												This was one of the earlier First-Person Shooters I played growing up. It's a decent game, but shows its age in its gameplay.PROS+Mechanically sound. Gunplay works accurately, and is one of the first FPS games where being able to look up and down is more than useful: it's necessary.+Wide variety of difficult enemies to kill, from lethal Ogres to tanky Death Knights to Zombies that just won't stay down.+Among the first games to incorperate jumping and swimming well.+Instead of being openly demonic, game takes more of a gothic approach with only one monster that's clearly a demon instead of a monster.+Greatly atmospheric, with cold, dark, and slimy level designs.+Added some mechanics which have become a staple of arcade FPS games ever since (such as rocket jumping, bunny hopping, and changing the direction of your jump midair).+Paved the way for many mods which would turn into their own games (such as Team Fortress)+Includes support for OpenGL which really helps the graphical quality.CONS:-Weapons work differently, which is initially confusing. Shotguns are similar to Doom or Duke Nukem, with an instant hit/miss with each pull of the trigger. Machineguns (called Nail Guns in game) fire slow-moving projectiles, which require more leadtime to be useful.-Some levels are confusing and frustrating to advance in.-Console commands necesary to enable mouse look every time you load the game, something which (I would think) be able to switch on and leave on.It's fine, and I had fun playing it, but be aware that it's very much a product of the times, and it shows in more ways than the graphics.

er 23, 2016
												Ah, Quake...how much we, the gamers of the 21st century owe thee So much of the technology and so many of the conventions we now take for granted were developed for this game. So many great games were built within the Quake engine or its immediate derivatives. It is truly a landmark of gaming history. Some of the greatest geniusus of game development history invested their talents into this game and changed the industry forever.But that's not why you should buy Quake. You should buy this game because it is still one of the best shooters ever made. It's stilll scary and exciting in equal measure. Its design is still darkly original, it's arsenal still finely balanced, and its gameplay still wickely slick.Once you are done with the ~9 hour campaign, why not check out the multiplayer that remains active more than twenty years after the game's release (if that's not proof enough of Quake's superiority, then nothing is). Or perhaps you could head over to Quaddicted.com and try any one of the 1200 user-made single player maps and map packs.For two decades Quake has been an unexhaustable source of pleasure for gamers and I full expect to still be basking in its glory twenty years hence.

												I just installed it today - I played the game waaay back when it was FIRST released(my current phone is more powerful than my first PC!) - and it runs just fine on our run-of-the-mill Windows 10 all-in-one desktop machine.  I did bump up the resolution from its default to something abit more modern, and it takes abit of getting used to(again) the fact that the mouse-looking is just side-to-side, but it doesn't matter at all, though there are keyboard keys for looking up-down. ***This game still holds up today, 20 years after its release.  You will quickly realize how much hand-holding is built into today's games!  Quake is THE game that made me a PC gamer.***It has been brought to my attention that there are various mods available that address certain 'quirks' of Quake that may make the game more enjoyable/accessible to modern gamers.

y 1
												very fun and educational

, 2011
												While modern iterations of the Quake franchise continue to attract new players, there has recently been a clear recognition of the true importance of the very first Quake in shaping the multiplayer FPS games we play today. Clients such as ezQuake, nQuake, and FuhQuake all continue to prolong the multiplayer life of this true classic as well as adding the various options, toolsets, and graphical improvements that most are familiar with today. From Dennis 'Thresh' Fong winning John Carmack's Ferrari 328 at the 1997 Red Annihilation Tournament to the current Quake Live MLG, CPL, Intel Masters, Tek9, and QuakeCon events (to mention just a few), there has rarely been a lapse in the competitive interest this game continues to generate.It is now 20 years since the game's release and there are simply too many happy memories to recount. Without a doubt one of the greatest games ever made and an essential title in any game collection.

												Doom for its time was an extreamly great game and still widely played today, in my opinion Quake shares that throne, the throne made of pure gold and big enough to seat 3 important FPS franchises by one developer, and WAY too heavy to be stolen even if every single other franchise tried at once with a heavy duty constuction crane (you know those big ones they use to build big apartment buildings?).The third important FPS is wolfenstine, but that is for another review.In quake you play as a person whos name I have forgoten (if he even has a name, i don't know a lot about the lore) andhave to go through 4 episodes of ancient castles and fortresses in order to collect 4 ancient runes needed to banish a horible evil entity known as shub-niggurath a huge monster and the only way to defeat it, is telefraging it.Not only was quake one of the first TRUE 3D FPS's it's also the start of the team fortress franchise, that's right you know the original rocket launcher for the solider? it's actually the rocket launcher from this very game.When starting it's pretty unique i'm not going to spoile it but, you might like it.The enemies are distinct from each other you got the knights who rush you with a sword, you got the flying monster (whos name i forgot) and then you got the ogre (no not shrek) who can just ♥♥♥♥ off and the blob monster in the last episode can get double f**ked on a pile of spikes because it hops around so damn fast you can barly hit it, these are all enemies you love to hate.anyway i'm not going to waste anymore of your time play this game or look for other reviews on steam or on youtube.

y 10
												NOTE: If the game doesn't have mouse look enabled, press ` and type +mlook , then hit enter. If you want the no-look experience bear in mind there are some enemies and switches that you can't hit without it.THOUGHTS:If you want the old school experience, the best way to get it is buy playing something that is from the time, and this is one of the best examples. To give you an idea, difficulty and missions are not selected in a menu, instead when you first play (and between chapters) you enter a small hubworld where you enter portals and tunnels to chose diffuculty and missions. There are even dangers and secrets in the hubworld as well! The highest nightmare difficulty is hidden in the hubworld as well, and I'm not sure if you can get to it without using console commands (someone tell me if there isn't)Just buy it tbh.

er 31, 2016
												Quake is, in my opinion, far more revolutionary to the FPS genre than DOOM.Quake pioneered: Mouselook/WASD Swimming Rocketjumping/bunnyhopping Polygon models Level design via enemy archtypes and placement relative to 3D gemometry MachinimaSadly, steam's digital download doesn't feature the soundtrack. Just open up the track per level via youtube.It's also a shame that we haven't had a proper sequal in over 20 years (if you don't fight entities straight out of Lovecraft with a bloody battleaxe, shotguns, nailguns and explosives in medieval settings, it's not canon).If you remotely consider yourself a fan of the FPS genre, buy this game, it's your history.

												It's funny to think that without Quake the gaming industry would be much different.Without Quake, Valve wouldn't have used its engine to create Half-LifeMeaning we wouldn't have the Hl mods that became games like Counter StrikeNeither would the Team Fortress mod exist meaning we wouldn't have its money printing sequelWe wouldn't even have Steam because Valve wouldn't have created Half-LifeWe wouldn't have speedrunning, completionism, modding or machinima be as big in the gaming community.So more than half of the gaming industry would be somewhat affected.Just let that sink in.By the way Quake is great you should play it, as well as 2 and 3.
